newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan parties reject "one country, two systems".
newsitem.headline: Taiwan parties reject "one country, two systems".

text.p: Taiwan's main political parties, though sharply divided over the island's future, have one thing in common -- they say the "one country, two systems" formula being pioneered in Hong Kong is inapplicable in Taiwan.

The parties -- from pro-reunification to pro-independence -- have hailed the end of 156 years of British colonial rule in Hong Kong but called the concept of local autonomy under communist China's rule unacceptable for Taiwan.

Taiwan President and ruling Nationalist Party chairman Lee Teng-hui has called Hong Kong's return to China "a delightful thing". The fledgling New Party, the staunchest advocate of unification among Taiwan parties, calls Hong Kong's return "a glorious page for the Chinese nation".
Even the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party described the handover as "positive".
But none of them want the same for Taiwan.

"No people in Taiwan will accept 'one country, two systems' under which Taiwan becomes a local government of the People's Republic of China," New Party leader Chen Kuei-miao told Reuters in an interview.

Beijing, which has viewed Taiwan as a rebel-held province since a 1949 civil war split it from the mainland, says the long-negotiated returns of Hong Kong and Macau in 1999 leave Taiwan as the only territory still awaiting "reunification with the motherland".
China says its handling of Hong Kong's "one country, two systems" experience should reassure Taiwan of its own future under mainland sovereignty.
Under the system agreed by Britain and China in 1984, Hong Kong can maintain its capitalist systems for 50 years after it reverts to Beijing's control on July 1.
Beijing has pledged that Taiwan would have even greater autonomy if it accepted "one country, two systems".
But President Lee flatly rejects Beijing's scheme for Taiwan's return. Lee's exiled Republic of China government favours an eventual reunion under democracy.
The Nationalist government, which has embraced multiparty democracy, says reunification is impossible before the Communist Party drops its political monopoly and allows democratic pluralism.
Chen said his New Party proposes that Taipei and Beijing should first reunite under a federation so Taiwan can continue to maintain its own defence and foreign affairs.
As for the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party, party lawmaker and Hong Kong affairs expert Lin Tso-hsui said Taiwan already was an independent sovereign nation, unlike Hong Kong.
"Taiwan is not a colony of any country. It rules itself. It has its own democracy," Lin said.
"'One country, two systems' is poison coated with sugar. Whether or not we will accept the offer? I'd say: No, thanks."
Democratic Progressive spokeswoman Sisy Chen was extremely skeptical about the "one country, two systems" model, saying it was impossible to integrate communism with capitalism.

"It's the first time in human history that they try to push these two ideologies together," the independence-minded Sisy Chen told Reuters. "It would be a very dangerous experiment. It's a fatal experiment."

If the formula succeeds in Hong Kong, Beijing's communists could find themselves with an even bigger problem at home as mainland cities such as Shanghai start to clamour for Hong Kong-style liberties, Chen said.
If the capitalism-under-communism experiment fails, even more Taiwan people will opt for independence, politicians said.

"If Hong Kong's economy declines and freedom and democracy go backward after the handover, this will trigger Taiwan people's independence sentiment and boost the separatist movement," Chen of the New Party warned.
The party leaders differed over Taiwan's future relations with Hong Kong and China.
The Nationalists and New Party said Taipei should keep close contacts with Hong Kong.
The Democratic Progressive Party said Hong Kong should be treated cautiously and as a foreign country.
